1.title: 19 Candles Acrostic

choices: Add a funny birthday memory here
add a funny birthday memory here
11.content:
My children's birthdays are a few days apart. We've always given them separate celebrations. On a cruise once, we opted to have a cake brought out to both of them at the same time.

The waiter brought out an 'anniversary' cake instead of a 'birthday' cake. The expressions on my kids faces were priceless, and we all laughed so hard!
11.title: funny birthday memory

111.content:
This is a funny birthday memory about Writing.Com, which was originally called, "Stories.Com".

On September 9, 2000, my friends, Santy and Amanda started bombarding me with emails to come and join Stories.Com. They said it was wonderful and we could write to our hearts' content in an Interactive Story. At that time we wrote about the characters of Sam and Josie from the movie, Never Been Kissed.

I was a bit timid, but they talked me into it and I joined, created a briefcase with the username of Carolinenbk and wrote something short in their Interactive Story, which was called "Bananas in Pajamas" or something like that. When I finished, I mistakenly ended the entire story, so that it said, "The End."

I was so ashamed and embarassed, but I emailed Santy and she said she had the power given to her by SM to edit and fix my boo boo.

I was very relieved and from that day forward I learned to be very careful on what I clicked on, especially when working on Interactive Stories.

This is the real tHiNg



** Image ID #1996280 Unavailable **
111.title: Add a funny birthday memory here

choices: Comedy or Drama, Share Your Trauma
1111.content:
I am going to write here. I saw that I wrote before and came here intending to tell the same story!

I did share this anecdote somewhere else, but originally here instead of "preferred" we would be promoted to "cool".

I remember that staff had to tell us that it wasn't "cool" to lobby to be "cool"

Then after a while I was promoted to Moderator, but some Moderators did not want me there because I wrote fan fiction. That was interesting but they soon eliminated the practice of the Moderators discussing prospective promotions. I got to read some things that were....well unsavory and they were about me!

I chose to stay yellow, then went away. Then I came back and was promoted to blue again after about three years. My husband, who is way smarter than I'll ever be, was promoted very quickly - I think he was in one of the first groups. He is still here because I pay to basic him, but isn't blue anymore because he never comes here. He is registered and hasn't been here since about 2007 or so. But I fill him in on all the scoop.
1111.title: Comedy or Drama?  Share the Trauma

choices: The best present you ever received
11111.content:
This will actually be a mix of both... And coincidentally, it's a memory from my sweet 16.

I don't remember exactly what it was that I did, but there was this one night, early on in the school year and before the new calendar year, when I made my mom really, really mad at me. I was 15, and in 10th grade. She yelled at me, "You know what? Your sweet 16 is CANCELLED! I was going to make it a nice surprise for you and all that, but after your behavior tonight, you don't deserve it."
Like I said, I really don't remember what spurred that reaction. I only remember having to write a reflection, saying "What I did was wrong; I did it because of this reason, and I know it was wrong. I promise not to do it again, but I don't think it's fair to take away something I didn't even know I had. Like one of my older friends said, a sweet 16 is like a gateway into adulthood, and I really wish you hadn't told me it was cancelled- I wasn't even expecting one, so had you just taken away something else, it probably would've been easier that way too, then just not have the party at all, like it wasn't even planned."

Fast forward through to January-ish, and my yearbook editor (in high school) is messing around with my friend Eleni, pulling tricks on her and such. I told him, "it's not nice to mess with other people, y'know."

Another month later, Eleni and I are sitting next to each other on the bus up to the other high school for a cancer awareness walk, because both schools on the hill had a student with Lymphoma (I think). So I ask her, "hey, are you free on X day at X time? Do you wanna go see a movie?"
That day and time was the exact timing of my sweet 16. It was back on, and I was fully aware of most of the plans- I had chosen the guest list, but they were all told this was "top secret", and I was, under no circumstances, to be told about the party.
Eleni, being the nice girl she was, became rather uncomfortable and didn't quite know what to say, besides, "Umm, I'll have to check. I think I'm busy though, I'm sorry!"
The day of the party, Eleni was sitting close to me, when she overheard me saying something about "Yeah, I knew this was going to happen." Her eyes went wide, and she asked me, "So you knew all along? You were just messing with me?"
I laughed as a response and told her, "Yeah."
11111.title: Comedy or Drama, Share Your Trauma

1113.title: Your Memory

choices: what kind of birthday memory do you recall
what is your best gift ever
you decide the direction to go.
112.content:
I like to go down memory lane, but my lane is full of curves...lol
I recall when I was four years old, I went to a birthday party at a neighbor's house and they were playing all of these party games, like pin the tale on the donkey. There was another game, I don't know what the name of it was; but the obstacle was to take a spoon full of beans from one bowl to another bowl across the room and the first person to have all of the beans from one bowl to the other was the winner. Any way I was so young and dumb I didn't know what to do with the beans so I just put the spoonful of beans in my mouth and chewed them up and ate them. Everyone at the party started laughing at me for being so goofy and doing such a foolish thing.

Then you would think as I aged I'd get smarter but not me. I recall my eighteenth birthday, my friends and I were in vocational school, and we decided to skip school for the day and get drunk since I was finally old enough to do so. I must say that I don't think there is any kind of sick like that, is there? I was so stupid because I live in a Dry county in Kentucky, which means there is no alcohol allowed in the county. We went to the next county over and got it and I was so afraid that people would know I was drunk that we passed by these two older pentecostal women and I was so afraid that they could smell the vodka and beer from within our car that I actually ducked down in the floor of the back seat. My friend and I got so tickled that we died laughing until we got sick that is, which lasted all night long...
112.title: add a funny birthday memory here

1123.content:
Usually in India, the child's FIRST birthday (one year old) is celebrated in a big way. However, it usually ends up with the child, who is too young to understand what is going on, getting upset by the crowds of guests and crying.

So my parents decided to be different and do my THIRD (three years old) birthday in a big way, so that I would be old enough to understand that this is my important day.

The party was in the evening, on my third birthday.

I was so excited on the day that I wouldn't stop running around the house all morning, and kept disturbing my Mom, who was packing the 'return gifts' (party favours). These included sweets, and whenever Mom wasn't looking, I'd grab some and eat them. Soon, I was on a sugar high as well as excited.

I somehow grabbed a bottle of Cocoa Cola and continued to run around, and tripped.

The bottle broke, and I cut myself on a piece of glass.

So my Dad had to take me for an injection.

I don't 'remember' this myself, but I've heard it told so often (you never live down what you did as a kid) that I know this is what happened!!
1123.title: you decide the direction to go.

choices: Tell about a time where you received a surprise
Tell about a time where you hated a gift, but smiled anyway.
12.content:
In 2009, I decided to have a holiday party with some high school and college friends. I have always loved planning parties and I always loved asking Nan (my grandma) about party ideas. She would always help me plan parties.

Nan mentioned a Chinese Firecracker game that was played at one party she attended. It didn't have a religious theme to it, so friends of all faiths could play this game. Basically, you would pass around wrapped gifts and whichever gift or gifts you wound up with when a song ends, it/they was/were yours.

I thought it was a fun idea and instead of buying the typical gifts of expensive items, I made CDs, bought muffin mix, shampoos, bought some paperback books, inexpensive CDs, Ramen noodles, lotions, and a teddy bear. I wrapped all the gifts for the day of the party.

Well let me tell you, the game was a hit! Everyone was surprised by the gifts they received! Although they were inexpensive gifts, everyone acted like a five year old opening gifts. They loved the small trinkets and they loved playing that game!

Everyone enjoyed the party I threw, but they especially loved the Chinese Firecracker game that Nan suggested. Nan always had great ideas and I miss her.
12.title: tell about a fun party game

123.content:
I found this game online while planning my cousin's graduation party with Mom. We dubbed it the "forbidden words" game. Essentially, once all the guests arrive, or as they arrive, have them each pick a word from a hat/bag/whatever, then keep it with them. They are now forbidden to say that specific word for the rest of the party!

Fun ones we used were: good, no, yes, and thank you. The common ones you don't really think about when you're using them in every day life. "No" was especially fun, because our culture emphasizes food so much, so if you've gotten the "no" word, and someone is trying to give you food... Either you lose the game, figure out another way to say "no thanks!", or accept the food and keep eating!
123.title: Another fun party game!

Chip raised his arms in triumph and was rewarded with a second helping. Forty years later.... Mom said, "I'm so glad you'll be in town for your birthday Son. I'll get out the angel food cake pan..." " Please, anything but thar Mom ....

132.content: I loooove me some good chocolate cake. However, after my trip to Texas this past summer, I definitely have a new favorite: tres leches. We originally got one from the local supermarket for my aunt's birthday, and it was both of our first time trying it. She put it in the restaurant's fridge (Uncle runs a restaurant), but the fridge was kinda acting up, in the sense that it was colder than usual. One of the workers knew of the issue but forgot to mention it to anyone, so when the cake came out of the fridge that afternoon, it was semi-frozen, slightly crunchy, and slightly chewy.
132.title: begin again: your favourite cake

choices: Write about an unexpected b-day surprise!
1321.content:
When I was a around 5 years old, I asked my grandmother to make me one of her famous doll cakes. All of the granddaughters got one eventually, and I thought they were super pretty. The bottom was a bunt cake decorated like a ballroom gown, and in the hole, she put a barbie doll and frosted the bodice with delicate flowers to match the "skirt". My cousin had one that was gorgeous, all purple ribbons and pink flowers on a pretty white dress.

Gram agreed to make me one, so I was very excited. She asked what my favorite kind of cake was, and I told her with no hesitation: chocolate with peanut butter frosting.

You can image my horror when I saw that the doll's dress was peanut-butter brown with darker chocolate flowers and ribbons. But hey... she tasted good!
1321.title: Unexpected B-day Surprise

choices: What type of cake is your favorite? Ex: Black Forest, Red Velvet etc..
142.content:
Much Ado About Cake-A Three-Ring Circus


         What do you get when you cross a British mother-in-law, her German husband, and my Canadian mother all eating cake? A three-ring circus filled with cake that juggles and falls at death defying heights, tumbles like a clown, and flies through the air at incredible speeds.

No matter what we’re celebrating, cake is the most important part of the party. In my family, there is an un-written law instituted by the over ‘sixty five’ crowd that states you have to eat cake right after a heavy meal or you’ll faint. If you suggest we retire to the living room to relax—sudden headaches and gasps ripple through the dinner conversation.

The three-ring circus begins with the in-laws and my mom sitting and drooling while the table is cleared. A whole discussion commences about the type of cake that will be served. Memories of cakes through their childhood start up. My mother-in-law reminisces about the Battenberg cake her granny baked with soft spongy squares of yellow and pink. Her husband pipes in with a tale from Germany. During World War II, there was no cake while growing up but he enjoyed eating bugs as a treat. The conversation stopped as the homemade Black Forest cake slid out of the refrigerator and onto the table.

I served them a thick piece with cherries dripping down the sides and chunks of chocolate scattered on the glass plates. The chatter started up again with more conversation about the different cakes of the past. How my mother made cakes with coins wrapped in wax paper and buried them into the cake before she topped it with icing. My mother-in-law mentions her famous Butterfly Cakes and describes how to make them in every detail. Her husband interrupts and adds his comment how every piece of cake should have ice cream on it—any flavour.

The three-ring circus continued with my mom cutting a huge piece, her mouth wide-open, it juggled on the fork and looked like ‘The Leaning Tower of Pisa’. It climbed at a steady pace to her chin before it took a death-defying leap and splattered on her plate. A cherry coated in thick sauce tumbled like a clown down the front of my mother-in-law’s ample chest—it had a long way to travel. I’m thankful she asked for a tea towel to cover her blouse instead of a napkin. Her husband’s cake is like the brave man who flies out of the cannon—he talks while he eats and the crumbs fly at an incredible speed. With each bite, whip cream, cherry sauce, and chocolate crumbs build on his full moustache.

The show ended with them smacking their lips and praised the baker for a show-stopping cake. I know the entertainment is worth every splattered chunk, tumbled cherry and flying crumbs.

In a couple of weeks, I will have the joy of another family party. I can guarantee the same characters will be the stars—let the show begin!
142.title: cake

1423.content: Spring into Fall and the phenomenal 16th Anniversary of WDC, a real feat in online history! I have been here for 6 of them and can attest for its marvel! It is a place that ever changes and strives to keep up with the tech times to keep WDC current and on the leading edge. Yet one thing is constant, its warmth and kindness, honouring authors as they are. It provides a creative and non-judgemental space for people to share and develop skills and community spirit. The leadership sets the model and shows the way with inspiration and allowance, while setting clear guidelines and cool tips for writers. Ever expansive is scope, the joy vibe is alive and opportunity for growth is available to all. Thanks WDC! Happy 16th and many more.
1423.title: Spring into Fall Birthday 2016

choices: During the birthday party, cops stormed the builiding
Friends got confused and brought actual cats, not cat food
15.content:
Back in the day, my kids' birthdays were celebrated in a near by park, so the mess was contained. I'm shocked by what parents spend on birthdays. They have to be events, even when the kid is two years old and won't remember a thing. Parents pay upwards of $200 to have a particular place or event reserved. If you have the money, it's a great idea.

The kids do have a blast, though. One place to hold an event is like a giant gymnasium, with the entire floor padded. There's a ball pit, which I had to haul both my grandson's out of. And their dad got stuck, while trying to play it cool.

Our interactive is all about 15, so I added the years of all my grandchildren together, and it came to 15! How cool is that?

You can Google a search and find suggestions for party themes.

In September, my grandson will be six. His theme is all things cats. Rather than gifts, he wants his friends to bring cat food to be donated to animal shelters. His family will buy him presents.
15.title: kids love birthdays

info.brief_description: Interactive birthday anecdotes, jokes, poems, story to celebrate WDC  Birthdays: 19 years
info.description:
In honour of WDC 's Birthday--er Anniversary,
(how often does a birthday and annniversary fall at the same time?}
here is your invitation to join in a free for all Interactive activity. We began in 2015
so let's continue for it's phenonmenal 19th year.

The theme is birthday/anniversary and anything related to it..goes!
Stories, anecdotes, poems, jokes, fictional or personal, etc are all welcome.
Just choose a leading chapter from the entry before and write in your own unique way.

Keep it E for everyone!

When you are done your entry,
Just leave some chapter headings that relate to the theme:
could be a word like balloons, or a phrase like : Best present you ever received, or a continuation of what you began, or a free choice--to give everyone a chance to play. Have fun!

If you do not leave a chapter choice, it ends the stream!

Let the party begin!

PS. If you do not know where to begin or how to enter interactives, just drop me a line! Happy to help.
Some quick links to begin with and continue:
" WDC birthday 15th" 
"kids love birthdays" 
"birthday joke" 
"Add a funny birthday memory here" 
"Spring into Fall Birthday 2016"  Another great year!
"Comedy or Drama, Share Your Trauma" 
"WDC 16th birthday tribute" 
"Other" 

Or go to the bottom of any chapter to Recent Additions to find a stream. Have fun and


EXTRA EXTRA: each entry gets a ticket into a draw for an INTERACTIVES MB!
info.pretty_title: All About Birthdays Free for all!
